column1: During the last 3 months of pregnancy, large amounts of calcium and phosphorus are transferred from the mother to the baby so that the baby's bones will grow.
A premature infant may not receive the proper amount of calcium and phosphorus needed to form strong bones.
A lack of vitamin D may also lead to osteopenia in infants.
Vitamin D helps with the body absorb calcium from the intestines and kidneys.
Most premature infants born before 30 weeks have some degree of osteopenia, but will not have any physical symptoms.
Infants with severe osteopenia may have decreased movement or swelling of an arm or leg due to an unknown fracture.
Osteopenia is more difficult to diagnose in premature infants than in adults.

Therapies that appear to improve bone strength in infants include: - Calcium and phosphorus supplements, added to breast milk or IV fluids - Special premature formulas (when breast milk is not available) - Vitamin D supplementation for babies with liver problems
Studies have suggested that very low birthweight is a significant risk factor for osteoporosis later in adult life.
